Answer: Transfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quicklyTransfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quickly is that we are fitting new examples into our existing knowledge rather than forming entirely new categories. If we could teach machines to do the same, they would learn exponentially faster and apply that learning more effectively.Transfer learning is a very hot topic in AI research right now, so I expect major breakthroughs in the next few years. I think this may be sufficient to achieve artificial general intelligence, but even if not, it will dramatically extend the range of tasks that machines can accomplish.

Answer: I think creative storage to level the load curve can be accomplished with minimal cost and allow PV and wind to be built larger than the daily peak load. I would like to see domestic hot water tanks adapted for thermal electrical storage based on local grid voltage and frequency stabilization. In a small city, 50k individual hot water tanks store about 2 million gallons of hot water. With a tempering valve on each tank, the temperature in the tank can be raised to near boiling and drop as much as 50 degrees with no inconvenience to the occupants (800 million BTUs of flexible invisible storageI think creative storage to level the load curve can be accomplished with minimal cost and allow PV and wind to be built larger than the daily peak load. I would like to see domestic hot water tanks adapted for thermal electrical storage based on local grid voltage and frequency stabilization. In a small city, 50k individual hot water tanks store about 2 million gallons of hot water. With a tempering valve on each tank, the temperature in the tank can be raised to near boiling and drop as much as 50 degrees with no inconvenience to the occupants (800 million BTUs of flexible invisible storage capacity - the equivalent of a quarter million kWh). With a fairly simple controller (and local hardware threshold controls) the heating of water can store the energy transparently. The heating of water could be delayed when the voltage or frequency sags, and could be heated to higher temperature whenever there is excess generation. Those controls could be done from central computers or just left to smart tank controllers. With each tank operating individually the neighborhood resolution of storage and line regulation would be very precise. Raising the tank temperatures would increase losses so the tanks should have high R-value insulation. When retired they should be replaced with larger and better insulated tanks (larger tanks have both more volume, and more volume per surface area to reduce losses). Thermal storage would not replace the need for battery and inverter storage but it could significantly reduce the amount required and allow it to be used only when additional generation capacity is needed. The tank’s low temperature thermostat would always control the “on” condition to prevent any disruption of hot water in the building, and the high temperature thermostat would always turn off the element if the temperature (or in some cases also pressure) exceed the safe limit.Other similar delayed use storage might include “powerwall” batteries, either alone or attached to PV systems. Another possibility is EV vehicle to grid management of storage. Storage is the key to increased load saturation by PV and wind. The storage needs to be cheap, and reliable, and I would add distributed widely in the service area.

Answer: The next 5 years is not too long of a window. Therefore, the best tech is what the utilities are trying to deploy now: distribution circuit primary reclosers.A primary circuit with no reclosers is totally out for one mainline fault because the substation breaker locks open. One midpoint reclosers will allow the front half of the feeder to be restored in seconds if the fault is on the back half of the feeder. That's a 50% reliability improvement.More reclosers reduce the portion of the feeder out by isolating the fault area even smaller.The rub is, an installed reclosers costs about $50k or morThe next 5 years is not too long of a window. Therefore, the best tech is what the utilities are trying to deploy now: distribution circuit primary reclosers.A primary circuit with no reclosers is totally out for one mainline fault because the substation breaker locks open. One midpoint reclosers will allow the front half of the feeder to be restored in seconds if the fault is on the back half of the feeder. That's a 50% reliability improvement.More reclosers reduce the portion of the feeder out by isolating the fault area even smaller.The rub is, an installed reclosers costs about $50k or more.The next rub is that most reclosers are ganged three phase operation. So, two unfaulted phases where there is a single phase fault remain out pending repair.An average feeder is about 5–20 miles of main line wire and feeds 1000–4000 customers. A feeder lockout, then, affects thousands of utility customers.In my opinion, and that's all it is, every primary feeder in existence needs 10 reclosers on average, but PUCs don't really push utilities on it because regulators don't really understand the logic behind the reclosers and, even if they do, they let the utilities choose how to spend reliability dollars. This just dilutes the money's effects. I guess PUCs would rather push things like solar.All you need to impel greater reliability is a PUC regulation that a utility needs to bring say 5 feeders per year up to this spec. Within 3 years, a step change improvement will be seen in the utility reliability statistics.To your question, in the near term, this is where the grid is or should be going. When a tipping point quantity of reclosers is reached on the system both interfeeder and intrafeeder, restoration switching steps can be given over to the computer. Great in a storm situation. HAL, where are you??

Answer: There are no smart grids online at this time. The other answers all describe aspects of what a smart grid would look like but none exist now.The current grid was designed for very centralized production and then distribution across large areas with only 4 major control centers for the whole US.This is not compatible with multiple geographically dispersed production centers with distribution and control over relatively small areas.The use of multiple renewable energy (wind and solar) sites that vary with sunlight and wind creates a problem that results in overproduction (resulting in curtailingThere are no smart grids online at this time. The other answers all describe aspects of what a smart grid would look like but none exist now.The current grid was designed for very centralized production and then distribution across large areas with only 4 major control centers for the whole US.This is not compatible with multiple geographically dispersed production centers with distribution and control over relatively small areas.The use of multiple renewable energy (wind and solar) sites that vary with sunlight and wind creates a problem that results in overproduction (resulting in curtailing) or underproduction (resulting in the use of expensive gasoline powered turbines).Reverse production flows mess up relays and power stations making reverse metering a problem.A smart grid would have to be built without disturbing the existing grid and would likely require mostly new infrastructure, poles, wires, control centers, power stations, etc. This will require the acquisition of a great deal of land that can only be taken from private owners. Estimates for a smart grid range from $1 to $1.75 trillion and from 10 to 25 years to build.

Answer: Well, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technologWell, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technology and networks, RAM memory, hard disk drives, liquid-crystal displays, lithium batteries, so on.But all that kind of stuff was developed by having governments getting involved, funding research and science and so on.Which, as we all know, is a really inefficient method, it pretty much doesn’t work.Instead of this inefficient method that clearly doesn’t work, of having governments take part in research and development, we now have a much better strategy for innovation:Random guys in their garage!As we all know, that’s where all the true innovation comes from, random middle class dudes, who have ideas, and then do a startup in their garage.Either that, or huge corporations who invest in ways to extend their patents.So now, we have much more groundbreaking innovation.We have things like Amazon, who patented and made a fortune off one-click buying, the truly revolutionary idea of not making people click more than needed.Do you really think that government could have ever come up with a brilliant idea like that, huh?

Answer: Q: What technology that doesn't exist yet would you like to see arrive within the next decade?(within the realm of what is possible or probable)With respect to space elevators, transporters, and nanotechnology surgery…First, I would interpret the above as technology ready to use and delivered to the market place and available to the consumer within 10 years.I wish to borrow from NASA’s/DOD’s Technology Readiness Level (see below). Substitute space/mission/flight with marketplace. To be available within the next decade I would imagine we would need something in aSo what wouldQ: What technology that doesn't exist yet would you like to see arrive within the next decade?(within the realm of what is possible or probable)With respect to space elevators, transporters, and nanotechnology surgery…First, I would interpret the above as technology ready to use and delivered to the market place and available to the consumer within 10 years.I wish to borrow from NASA’s/DOD’s Technology Readiness Level (see below). Substitute space/mission/flight with marketplace. To be available within the next decade I would imagine we would need something in aSo what would I like to see?An interface/application abstraction layer for common purpose applications (spreadsheets, word processors, delivery of news service, media delivery, discussion groups, encyclopedia/web-reference)A less technical way of saying it is provide a familiar user experience.For example: I buy a new car, I recognize the steering wheel, the speedometer, etc… I do no require retraining to move between car to car (hopefully). There is this thing called negative habit transfer. The old dog/new tricks scenario. Some people have a talent for jumping between interfaces. Those people are already rewarded in the job market. Others…not so much so I ask why does industry have to bear the brunt of significant retraining, and likely errors, in retraining if the task hasn’t changed.Three examples:-Let’s say the brand new Excel 2019 has a whole bunch of stuff, but has a switch that offers (Excel97/2003 interface). Or Openoffice has a switch that sets to (Excel97/2003 interface). Heck why not make Word2020 look like WordPerfect 5.1 should the user choose. It should be just a shell.-Let’s say I want to view CNN, BBC, or CBC base news site, there is a reader that presents different content from different providers in a common way, selected by the user.-Let’s say someone is accomplished in any number of computer languages and wants to script a task at the application level. why can’t they select a language of choice or even pseudeo-code or even mix and match snippets of a bunch of languages.Such a concept would be counter to many efforts to “improve” interfaces but it seems now a lot of effort isn’t to improve the interace but support the “clickbait” or “latest version” push of revenue models.I know this was a pipe dream that seemed to happen for a short time with HTML, W3C, and early windows/mac based application (think some linux people might be a ray of hope). With so many apps, IDE, and interfaces now it’s seems to be off the rails. We also had most of the 20th century where if one opened a book one expected a structure of table of contents, chapters, index etc.Given the current state of technology, if my 99 year old grandmother was comfortable and had reinforced behaviors that allowed her to function with skills in Windows 95, why should she have to learn new skills? Why can’t the salesperson upon deliver say “Siri, give this iPad a win95 look and feel” and the appropriate royalties be paid for at time of purchase.We are talking about the outside interface, not the internal guts. There is already a hardware abstraction layer between the software and firmware/hardware. Why can’t there be a Interface abstraction layer between the software and the WetWare ( namely the idiot-old-fart wondering where all my Excel menus went and why are these buttons taking up so much real estate on the damm screen) That way the teenager can use the voice/image capture gesture tech or whatever is the next interface and I can still expect to seeWhat I am saying is the next generation in detail hiding. Let computers be computers and let people be people. We’re getting there.Note: I was using “idiot-old-fart” term reflexively. :-)
